intro:
User from the Void.

--------

- [Dark ZeroMe](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1HmJ7GadjdiQUPevaK7QXVrK4nhyCp1fSj/) - If you hate white, come join us on the dark side.
- [8values on Zeronet](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1GhQnhzopJKP1RUKX8cd55CSXXSygzPFYj/) - Find out how you lean in politics.
- [Blog](http://127.0.0.1:43110/19Bb6RMYZGTDZJduj5q5Zz8uaBgNtHnCeH/) - So far used mostly to post updates of my various ZeroNet projects.
- [TED Talks 2017 - Speakers List Archive](http://127.0.0.1:43110/14MQWAD4DNSWx52pidtux4oQXz4gTn4B5f/) - Archive of speakers from when the ZeroNet founder was slated to appear at the conference.
- [Share Test](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1FyYahC8sKVYfsPQXEzuRjXNDQeb6Y2xno/) - Experiments with file sharing and video streaming using ZeroMux.
- [Contact Me](http://127.0.0.1:43110/mail.zeroverse.bit/?to=jayofthezero)

post.body: Welcome to the Zero. I am Jay of the Zero. Pleased to meet you.
Still confused about how exactly the Hubs work. Can you switch between them or what? I think I'm on Blue hub...
How do you clone ZeroMe? I'm interested in creating a Dark themed version, but got tripped up out of the gate :(

Ok. So my ZeroMe clone is semi-functional. Things like Activity Feed and Following are busted, and I can't figure out why. They simply don't show up. 

I've deleted ZeroMe.db so that it could be regenerated, but the newly generated file is still 100KB smaller than the original ZeroMe.db. This suggests that it's missing something, though I haven't been able to check what exactly. But the real question is why is it missing data?

ZeroMe itself is still perfectly functional, so that shows that the Hubs themselves are fine. So that means that the problem is with my clone, but I just can't find the reason. I only changed a total of three files:

* all.css - modified
* content.json - newly made
* ZeroMe.db - deleted and regenerated

Did I miss something?

AAUUGGGHHH!!
(ノಠ益ಠ)ノ Why?

Why are my ZeroMe clones screwed up!? Now the Activity feed is even showing up in the Profile page? Why!? I literally copy&pasted it without changing anything except *content.json* and *all.css*.

Щ(º̩̩́Дº̩̩̀щ)

And on top of that they think my hub is Red hub for some reason. I even checked all of the hub data using @Kaffie's guide and everything properly points to my Blue hub profile. So why does it think I'm Red?

I want to cry ( ╥_╥)

So I'm still having issues with my ZeroMe clones. Here's an image to better show my issues:

https://gateway.ipfs.io/ipns/QmcpgDW1BPEqBwbzq2JmySkFmcmAE9k1aV5kDeV5S5XxMk/2016-08-13%2009_11_45-ZeroMe%20Clone.png

I've straight up copy&pasted ZeroMe several times now, but the same issues keep appearing. Original ZeroMe works fine though. I'm honestly lost at this point.

Ok, seeing as I'm having issues with my own account I want to at least confirm my ZeroMe clone is working.

##So I now present "Dark ZeroMe"

http://127.0.0.1:43110/1HmJ7GadjdiQUPevaK7QXVrK4nhyCp1fSj

Please give it a whirl :)

After it asks to merge, simply select your username and wait a bit as it loads. All your ZeroMe data should load and it should operate just as ZeroMe would.

I created this as the white theme of ZeroMe is quite glaring at night, and doesn't look so good when using *f.lux*. After hearing how ZeroMe is pretty much just a front-end for the hubs that hold all of the actual data, I realized that means anybody can create/modify their own ZeroMe "client". And thus *Dark ZeroMe* was born!

Ok, I was able to fix my login in a ZeroMe clone by copying the ZeroMe.db file from a working ZeroMe to the non-working one. Of course this doesn't help people having the issue that don't already have a working ZeroMe. Still need to track down what exactly is missing before we have a solid fix. Though @Nofish will probably just fix the root cause before then.

Ok, just pushed out the latest tweaks to  [Dark ZeroMe](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1HmJ7GadjdiQUPevaK7QXVrK4nhyCp1fSj/).

I realized that I hadn't accounted for code markdown thanks to @Kaffie's post so I threw that in last minute.

I'm still looking for impressions on Dark ZeroMe's theme and functionality. Any comments would be apreciated.

I noticed @Scrub's comment about a Markdown tooltip in the posting box, and I'm looking into it for Dark ZeroMe, but it probably won't be coming in a hurry. I need to design how it'll fit into the page, and then figure out how to cram it into *all.js*, neither of which will be easy for me.

Anybody know how to exempt localhost from UI_password? With Proxy DNS resolving on URLs I get asked for a password every time I visit a site. It's getting annoying and dampens the convenience of the shortened URLs.

Fun Fact: I'm currently seeding 87 Zites, with a total disk usage of 376MB. 

If you average that out that's about 4.3MB per zite. Pretty good cost ratio there. With today's storage prices I could easily host several thousand zites for around $10, which is the cost of a 32GB sdcard that I could leave plugged into my laptop. Sure in the future zites will get bigger, but that's still easily a few thousand. Can't wait for there to be more interesting zites to seed.

Sorry for the delay Dark ZeroMe users. I just pushed the latest update using the latest ZeroMe code. This includes the new Follow mentions/comments feature. Just take note that you shouldn't follow both ZeroMe and Dark ZeroMe, otherwise you'll get duplicate updates from both sites. If you've followed ZeroMe and not Dark ZeroMe, those updates will link you to ZeroMe. So just be aware that clicking on those updates in Hello Zeronet will take you to the bright white theme of ZeroMe. 

Again sorry for the delay. I had finished merging the code last night, but then I passed out, slept through my alarm, and woke up at noon. So the yard work I was planning on doing in the cool morning had to be done in the hot sun :P So I didn't have a chance to publish the update until just now.

Cool, I got Zeronet proxied to my phone. :)

I already had an SSH server on my home network, so I just connected to it using ConnectBot and made a port forward from local port 43110 to my machine running Zeronet. Now I can easily access Zeronet through http://localhost:43110 with any browser on my phone. This also means most Zeronet links work as well. :D

PS: No root needed ;)
Pushed latest merge for Dark ZeroMe. The new ZeroMe "Follow New Followers" option should now appear.

#SOS:
My ZeroHello feed is missing after I updated ZeroNet. It's just blank. I still have my list of sites and the buttons in the top left, but none of the menus work and the feed is just white space.

http://pastebin.com/yLb1vVFY

EDIT: For some reason Zeronet is also ignoring --ui_ip *

http://pastebin.com/e7WmMgh8

Great... Now Firefox won't load any Zeronet pages for some reason. I get the background of ZeroHello and that's pretty much it. Pages load fine in Chrome, so I have no idea what's causing the issue in Firefox so suddenly.
It's moments like now when the posting rate is nearly non-existent that makes me realize we still have a lot of work to do :)

Merged latest ZeroMe changes into Dark ZeroMe. Accidentally broke some of my CSS while merging, which I think I managed to fix afterwards, but if you notice anything wonky please let me know.

In the future I plan on modularizing my CSS from the normal ZeroMe CSS in order to ease future merges, but I need to find time in order to to extract my theming from the current code. The current direct edit method caused by my laziness coming back to bite me :P
@Nofish: Where's the ZeroHello Newsfeed follow data stored? I somehow got myself stuck with something in my feed that no longer exists. :\

That moment when you realize your site hasn't been working for five frustrating hours because you mixed up Javascript and Python comment methods :P

Anyway, I'm pushing the ZeroMe updates to Dark ZeroMe right now. Let me know of any issues.

Anybody else having issues with ZeroMail? I checked it today and noticed I had a message, but when I tried to reply the submit button was greyed out. Tab+Enter would let me finally press the button, but the message never actually gets sent. Also I can't view my sent messages either.

I've tried wiping browser cache, using a different browser, and even deleting and re-downloading ZeroMail, but I still get the same issue.
Test
Yes, I'm updating Dark ZeroMe with the new ZeroMe features if anyone was wondering.

Test

| Tables        | Are           | Cool  |
| ------------- |:-------------:| -----:|
| col 3 is      | right-aligned | $1600 |
| col 2 is      | centered      |   $12 |
| zebra stripes | are neat      |    $1 |

Markdown | Less | Pretty
--- | --- | ---
*Still* | `renders` | **nicely**
1 | 2 | 3

Quick, run to Canada!
https://i.redd.it/l3gdg40j1hwx.gif

I know you like posting pictures guys, but at least put some text to hint at what it is. Remember pictures don't auto load, so you have to explain what it is a bit so people can decide whether it's worth downloading.
I really need to update my Dark ZeroMe, but I've been so busy :P
Test

##Dark ZeroMe Updated

All 20-50 of you can stop being annoyed at me now XD

I've finally gotten around to updating Dark ZeroMe to be in parity with standard ZeroMe. Though I still don't have time to implement any of the extras that things like ZeroMe+ have.

You can tell you got the update by the "updated Mar 6, 2017" added next to the logo. Though you might need to clear your browser cache to get it completely working.

As always if you think I've missed anything please let me know.

PS: If anybody knows where is the javascript/css for the slight blue glow when you select the comment textbox, I'd appreciate it. I haven't managed to track it down, though it's probably obvious and I'm just stupidly missing it.

Update: I also went through and cleaned a few things up and excluded some random extra backup files that have been included by accident. Oh, and I threw in the new extra languages.

[Link to Dark ZeroNet](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1HmJ7GadjdiQUPevaK7QXVrK4nhyCp1fSj/)

###Quick Update to Dark ZeroMe

---
I realized that NoFish added a class to the @ mentions, and realizing that black text on dark grey isn't the best, I tried adding some light grey background to it, rounded the corners, and padded it out. Let me know what you think.

PS: I also changed the black text in the user listings to a dim orange since that was even worse than the @ mentions.

UPDATE: I tweaked the @ mentions a bit more, then had to tweak the Code boxes since they were now colliding with the @ mentions. I think I've gotten everything balanced now, though let me know your opinions.

@Nofish: 

Question,
Why did you base64 encode the fonts directly into the ZeroMe CSS? Wouldn't it be a better idea to just include them as separate files?

Thanks for your time.

##Quick DZM Update

---
Merged latest ZeroMe update. New "Liked" filter shows only posts you've liked. Hovering over Activity Feed updates shows full post in tooltip.

#PSA:

If you want to post a link to a ZeroMe post on Dark ZeroMe or ZeroMe Plus you should replace everything before the `/?` with a `.`.

For example, here's a URL to a post I made:
`http://127.0.0.1:43110/1HmJ7GadjdiQUPevaK7QXVrK4nhyCp1fSj/?Post/1BLueGvui1GdbtsjcKqCf4F67uKfritG49/16nArdxrSaNThNp83kL8E6NLL9WD98iUne/1488835102`
The problem with this URL is that it'll redirect anybody using ZeroMe to Dark ZeroMe. 

But if I use this URL:
`http://127.0.0.1:43110/Me.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Post/1BLueGvui1GdbtsjcKqCf4F67uKfritG49/16nArdxrSaNThNp83kL8E6NLL9WD98iUne/1488835102`
People using Dark ZeroMe will be redirected to normal ZeroMe (blinding them in the process).

The solution?
`./?Post/1BLueGvui1GdbtsjcKqCf4F67uKfritG49/16nArdxrSaNThNp83kL8E6NLL9WD98iUne/1488835102`
Just make a link using Markup like so:
`[Click Me!](./?Post/1BLueGvui1GdbtsjcKqCf4F67uKfritG49/16nArdxrSaNThNp83kL8E6NLL9WD98iUne/1488835102)`
[Click Me!](./?Post/1BLueGvui1GdbtsjcKqCf4F67uKfritG49/16nArdxrSaNThNp83kL8E6NLL9WD98iUne/1488835102)

And the link will work no matter what ZeroMe you are using :)

Still thinking about the best way to link from outside ZeroMe though.

[Test Distributed Video Stream](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1FyYahC8sKVYfsPQXEzuRjXNDQeb6Y2xno/__example-player__.html)

Uses ZeroMux library over ZeroNet. No WebTorrent or IPFS. Should work on latest ZeroNet if UIPassword plugin isn't enabled. Might have issues in Chrome if using an HTTPS connection. Works best with Firefox.
LOL, I can't read half of what's on here anymore without GT. Guess that's a good sign though.

Well this is disturbing: 
https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2017/03/public-records-activist-violated-copyright-by-publishing-georgia-legal-code-online/

Anybody know a place that might've archived these? Archive.org sadly [didn't archive them](https://web-beta.archive.org/web/20151021075729/https://law.resource.org/pub/us/code/ga/
Georgia.scan.2013) since they were PDFs, and rather large ones at that. I want to share these via torrent/zeronet as no matter what copyright, if it's critical to how the law is judged then it deserves to be freely available to the public, *in its **complete** form*.

^edit: fixed broken links

Wish Qubes OS would officially support GPU passthrough and add a GUI for it. I'd switch in a heartbeat. I get they have security concerns, but being able to use a GPU in Windows is simply a requirement for me, and it sucks that I'm stuck on Windows because of it. If anybody knows a VM setup for Linux with easy GPU passthrough, that'd be a nice runner-up, please drop me a line.

Here's a new ZeroMux video streaming test. I wanted to see how well it handles larger videos, so here's an 18 minute one. Let me know how well it works. Might be slow to load for the first couple visitors since it's just me as the only seed to start, but theoretically things should speed up.

[Mobile Suit Gundam Thunderbolt Episode 1](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1FyYahC8sKVYfsPQXEzuRjXNDQeb6Y2xno/__example-player__msg-t.html)

PS: There's a bug in Chrome that prevents it from working properly, so I suggest using Firefox.

In case people missed it, I archived the TED Talk Speakers page from before they removed Nofish, so that we can dream of what could've been. I've preserved it here:
http://127.0.0.1:43110/14MQWAD4DNSWx52pidtux4oQXz4gTn4B5f/

How to get Zeronet to work over VPN Remote port? I have PIA VPN and tried to get Zeronet to work using their remote port feature, but even after connecting to the VPN and changing Zeronet's fileserver port to the port specified by the VPN, Zeronet claimed it was still closed.

#Come hang out with us on [0/Anime](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1JTecqHWYLQX2TUTvfGwbNgnLuDUhQNWCd/) 

Not much going on there yet, but hopefully the community can grow.

Is it possible to have Zeronet use a specific IP/Network Adapter? I want to leave my VPN on, but Zeronet can't open its port through the VPN so I just want it to go over my normal connection. I've been messing around with ForceBindIP, but Zeronet fails to start when I try to launch it through ForceBindIP.

Weird. Just upgraded my modem and now I can't get port `15441` to open. Zeronet told my modem using UPNP to open the port, and it says it did, but the external port checks turn up negative. I tried manually setting the port forward, and same result. Canyouseeme.org says it can't see it. You'd think it was my ISP, but I didn't have trouble with my previous modem. So you'd then expect my modem is to blame, but I've got several other ports opened through it and Canyouseeme says those are working fine. I'm stumped.

What was the Zeronet flag for changing the port? Maybe a different port will make it happy.

Yo, if you haven't watched "Kado" yet you should give it a shot. It's a thinking Sci-fi anime that approaches first-contact from an interesting angle. It's also got some of the best CGI yet in anime. Worth giving a shot if you were looking for something different. 

Streaming now on Crunchyroll(Global-Sub), Funimation(US-Dub), and VRV(US-Sub/Dub).
*Or wherever you get your anime from....*

I'm the 164th most active user!

Oh yeah 😎

*Totally Significant Awards, We Promise™*

I'm starting to think we need to have language filters on ZeroMe.

I like people from China, but you have to admit it gets tedious having to scroll through dozens of Chinese posts just to find one in a language I understand. Even if I try to participate in the Chinese posts it gets really cumbersome to translate everything using GT, even with the handy Firefox Addon I have, and even then the translation quality is mixed.

So @Nofish: Is it practical to implement such a feature? Maybe using the default language people have set? Though we'd have to figure out a way for people to post in a different language if they desire to...

A fellow user, @ScrubTheSecond: Posted an interesting quiz called "8values" on here a few days ago. It was actually really interesting, and from my unscientific testing, pretty accurate. However it was a clearnet site using third-party trackers, which is a big "No" for some fellow Zeronet users. But I realized that it was hosted on GitHub, and was in fact open-source. So I cloned it, removed all the third-party scripts, and thus created:

#[8values on Zeronet](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1GhQnhzopJKP1RUKX8cd55CSXXSygzPFYj/)

Please Enjoy 🙂

Sheesh, have you guys been uploading your entire music collections to ZeroMusic?

Not complaining, just amazed.... 😲

Whelp, I've had a fun day. My phone had a stroke yesterday; home button stopped working, notifications disappeared, bluetooth wouldn't connect, some apps randomly decided they weren't owned by me; you know, all the fun stuff. So I had to move 50GB of crap off my SD card to make space to backup my apps, and then wipe my phone, and now restore my 500+ apps and move all that crap back onto my SD card. Yay \o/

I hate how Google and app makers are cracking down on Rooted phones just because of fringe risks like Piracy and cheaters. Nobody would pirate something off a phone, there's easier ways to rip video, and for online cheaters there are plenty of ways a proper developer could mitigate cheaters on the server side. People teleporting in Pokemon Go? Well obviously if they traveled faster than an airplane could to a location than they are cheating, and simple server tracking of inventory could prevent somebody from gaining a million pokeballs. You have the algorithms at hand, you know how much should be possible in normal gameplay to predict this stuff, use them!
@sirenyc: Will ZeroMux be updated for the recent changes in ZeroNet, or is it dead for now?

Saw this article and it makes me disgusted by China's government even more.

https://fossbytes.com/china-installing-spyware-phones-muslim-xinjiang/amp/

Real shame too, because I love Chinese culture, but at this point I'd never want to go there.

Finally found a file transfer app that just works and isn't bogged down by a ton of crap. Things like SMB, FTP, HTTP, and such were just too slow and cumbersome for local network transfer between devices. I wanted something simple and drag&drop. Things like ShareIt used to be good, but they changed hands and were pumped full of ads and stupid crap.

##Enter in [**Dukto**](http://www.msec.it/blog/?page_id=11) *\(clearnet\)*

It's open-source and has apparently been around for years. Supports a bunch of PC and Mobile OSs, has no ads, and just does file transfer (plus clipboard text). Finally. 

##All hail the Green Pipe!

Anybody know details about **Sardex**? Saw a CBSNews video on it, but when I started digging for details most of the Videos and Articles are in Italian. The TEDx talk doesn't even have any captions. Google Translate also doesn't fair well with these technical articles.

Particularly I'd like a comparison in usefulness with cryptocurrencies like Bitcoin.

So the release of Firefox 57 is coming up, with it's abandonment of the old add-on platform. So to see how many of my addons make the transition so far, I downloaded the latest portable build of Firefox Dev Edition. I started it up, reasonably impressed with the new slimmed design and performance, then logged into sync to have it download all my stuff. 

The result? 4 addons installed. uBlock Origins, Pushbullet, Privacy.com, and Reddit Enhancement. That's it. 90% of my addons were rejected. Many of them are niche and my hopes for them getting updated by release of v57 are low. For others I've read several of the devs of my addons rant that it's pretty much impossible for them to move to WebExtensions since it doesn't have the needed APIs for their addons to actually do the thing they were designed for. 

So far things like Tab Groups are causalities because they don't have the needed APIs to actually "group" the tabs together and switch them out. Others like DownThemAll can't get any kind of direct file writing permission, which is needed for its bulk multi-threaded downloads to work. Greasemonkey isn't happy with the amount of control over incoming javascript they're allowed, as it's creating performance issues and security concerns. And the list goes on.

So I guess I'm stuck on old Firefox for a while. I've already disabled updates on my default Firefox DevEd v56b11. Any recommends on a Firefox fork that keeps support for the old addons while still receiving security updates and new features?

Testing Big File Video Sharing:
[The Co-Optional Podcast Animated - Quest Givers](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1uPLoaDwKzP6MCGoVzw48r4pxawRBdmQc/data/users/16nArdxrSaNThNp83kL8E6NLL9WD98iUne/The%20Co-Optional%20Podcast%20Animated%20-%20Quest%20Givers%20-%20Polaris-7mnvuoLs2wY.mp4)

@Emeraude: Are you going to leverage the new Big File support for ZeroMusic? I think it'd help improve performance a lot. Though I doubt you could retroactively improve all the previous uploads since they don't have piece maps.

Funny enough, I found a workaround for **ZeroUp**'s filetype limit. Back in ZeroNet v0.5.3 compressed archive support was added so you can compress files but still load them in the browser, but at the time it wasn't recommended to have archives larger than a few MB because of the lack of Big File support. So today I noticed somebody uploaded a BBC Radio MP3 as a TAR GZ file, and this reminded me of this feature and that note. So I thought, "What if I just added the location of the MP3 to the end of the URL to trigger the archive support?"

And guess what? [***It works.***](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1uPLoaDwKzP6MCGoVzw48r4pxawRBdmQc/data/users/1GL7wvqKyHd3yspwcM3tGQGdRgJZbvSGTu/SixOClockNews-20171006-6102017PMBrushesAsideLeadershipChallenge.mp3.tar.gz/SixOClockNews-20171006-6102017PMBrushesAsideLeadershipChallenge.mp3)

╰( ͡° ͜ʖ ͡° )つ──☆*:・ﾟ

EDIT: Looks like the compressed archive function doesn't know to first request the big file function to start downloading the file first. So you have to first get ZeroNet to start downloading the archive(easiest way is to click the "+Seed" button in ZeroUp), and then click the link to MP3 or whatever file inside the archive. Hopefully @Nofish: can correct this in the future so that the compressed archive feature can become more useful.

##Think I finally found my Firefox life raft. 

[**Waterfox**](https://www.waterfoxproject.org/) is based on Firefox with some privacy minded tweaks and unsigned extension support enabled. After they hit v56 later this month they'll be making it an ESR(Unlike Mozilla :P), so that it'll still get security fixes while still supporting the old Firefox addons that Mozilla plans to retire in Firefox v57. This should give me more time to either find alternatives to addons that won't make the transition, or wait for devs to finish the transition to WebExtensions. 

They've also announced tentative plans to completely fork Firefox v56 and continue development of the old Addon platform, as well as expanding the APIs for WebExtensions to enable close to the same flexibility as the old platform allows. If I just can't transition to FireFox v57+, depending on how well development on the new browser does I might permanently switch to it instead.

I've been playing around with this new compression tool called **CompactGUI**. https://github.com/ImminentFate/CompactGUI

It's pretty neat as it surfaces some hidden compression functionality in Windows 10 that allows seamless compression of programs and files without impacting the performance of those programs or reading of the files. Works great for games or even Adobe Photoshop with no perceivable loss in loading or fps.

Though I've made the mistake of trying it on the directory containing ZeroNet. With the thousands of small files in there the thing is taking forever, and I'm probably not actually gaining much out of it with all the constant changes being made to those files XP

Ugh, WaterFox isn't working out for me since it doesn't have, of all things, Pocket support. Mozilla picked up Pocket and integrated it into FF a while back, but the people who make WaterFox didn't like that so they stripped it from WF. Thing is, I use Pocket, and without that integration there's no decent way to use Pocket in WF. There's a third-party addon, but it doesn't support tags, which I use all the time.

Oh well, I'm back to FF56. It's starting to look like I'll have to make the jump to FF Quantum eventually now. Thankfully most of my addons have finally made the jump, or I've found decent alternatives. But two major missing addons is Session Manager and Tab Groups. The "alternative" recommended for Session Manager is an incomplete mess, and Tab Group like addons are currently impossible because all the needed APIs aren't ready yet despite them forcing the transition XP

The Quantum transition has been a complete mess.

comment.body: @Quadrangle - Wazzup
@Quadrangle - Does the content we post in one hub show up in the others? If not, how do we choose which to post in?
That does kinda make separate hubs pointless. I was more envisioning something closer to subreddits when I first heard about the feature.
Oh well. At least it's possible to create separate accounts so you can for example have your "AdminOfAwesomeSite" account, along with your personal one. All I need is a notification system now...
Sounds like fun. Wish the original concept of BTLive panned out as it would've been useful with such a site. Is there any alternative decentralized streaming app?
@Kaffie - I eagerly await such a decentralized Reddit. Facebook clone is nice and all, but I want to gather with people with similar interests in a place we can have discussions about said interest.
F*** your retarded username
@Renegadepatriot: At least she doesn't make stuff up at her convenience. Though honestly it's the choosing between the lesser of two evils this year. And voting for a third-party is pointless.
Yep
How exactly does SAFE compare to efforts like Tor, Zeronet, and IPFS?

@Kaffie: -Okay, got everything modified. And it's sortof working, but I can't sign-in to my ZeroMe account. I get faced with the Create Profile page and trying to "join" the Blue hub again results in an error saying that I already exist on that hub. This leaves me without any way to login to my account, though messages from other users do show in "Visitor mode". Help?-

@Kaffie: You're right after I replied it started working. Though it seems to be really slow in propagating the content. Some posts and users still haven't appeared, and my Follows still aren't listed.
Hmmm. It's really inconsistent with what shows up. A lot of stuff is missing for some reason and I can't figure out why.
@Kaffie: If by double hubbing you mean joining more than one hub, then I don't think I am. This really doesn't make sense why my clone isn't working. Maybe I'll try making it from scratch again.

Definitely would be interesting to see a Torrent site built with hubs. Just like ZeroMe, the Torrent site itself would just be a frontend, so people could basically design their own Torrent site and have it access the same databases. The hub design also means that people could "subscribe" to the content they want. So if people don't want to see NSFW stuff they just don't have to add that hub.
@Kaffie: Shameless self promotion XD
@Kaffie: Strange how it doesn't effect normal ZeroMe for me though. Unless that's because things are cached in ZeroMe.db... That might explain why only my clones seem effected.
@ZAlex: Sorry about that. Please try again. I made sure to use a proxy to check if it was working this time.
Weird, Blue hub is only 528kB for me.
@tkarita: Anything interesting in your log?
@Nofish:  Whoops, my bad. Should be fixed and published.

@Compumatrix: There seems to currently be a bug in ZeroMe. Try closing Zeronet and then copying "\data\1MeFqFfFFGQfa1J3gJyYYUvb5Lksczq7nH\merged-ZeroMe\ZeroMe.db" to "\data\1HmJ7GadjdiQUPevaK7QXVrK4nhyCp1fSj\merged-ZeroMe\ZeroMe.db" and see if that fixes the issue.

To change a page name, try changing everything using: "slug": "[NAME OF PAGE]"
To: "slug": "[NEW NAME OF PAGE]"

Also, Red links in the Index are generated whenever you create a link to a non-existent wiki page inside another page. So if you rename a page, make sure to change any links to that page, otherwise you'll end up with a Zombie red link in the Index.

They are just the "hubs" where your data is stored. It doesn't really matter which hub you're on, as inevitably people will eventually have all of them downloaded anyway, just by browsing ZeroMe.


Basically the Hubs act as separate databases where the user data is stored separately from ZeroMe. This helps provide a solution to the issue where users could run out of allowed space on a site, like ZeroTorrents, and not be allowed to post anything more because of it. The separation of the hubs on sites like ZeroMe means that even if you run out of space on one hub, you can move to a new hub and continue posting. Your posts and comments will still be tied to your account, just stored in a different hub, and they'll all appear in ZeroMe as long as you have the hubs downloaded.


Another benefit of the separation of the hubs from the site itself is that the original site isn't the only one that can use the hubs. This basically means that sites like ZeroMe are basically front-ends to the hubs, which also means that you can use different front-ends and still access the same data. Think of it like third-party Twitter clients on your phone. They each function differently, with different UIs and features, but they all connect to the same Twitter APIs and databases. So basically people can create their own modified ZeroMe sites, but still talk to people using the original ZeroMe.

To be fair, it just wasn't working out for them. They were sinking a ton of money into it and in the end the results just weren't worth it anymore. On the bright side this means they are shifting back to community based projects like Gnome and Wayland so we won't have a split ecosystem anymore just because Canonical wanted to do something different. Sucks that this means that Mobile and convergence projects are now dead, but it was really inevitable because of the current mobile OS market, and those two were pretty much the main reason why Canonical was pushing Unity and Mir in the first place.

Only for money? They're a company, and they were sinking a lot of money into a project that wasn't working out. That's no reason to not trust them anymore. They had a vision they were trying to reach but they just couldn't pull it off. Sure the developers that sunk time making their stuff compatible with Unity and Mir might feel miffed, but not much flat out relied on them for obvious reasons. I doubt the community will be hurt much if at all. In fact this means that Canonical will be getting back into Gnome and Wayland, which is a good thing for everyone.
@Plasmmer: So? Competition is competition. And besides, Microsoft hasn't had any success with Convergence yet either. Even Samsung is trying to get in on the game with their S8 and it's "DeX Dock".

@Plasmmer: Canonical is a company, and they were competing against other companies. They were doing this on their own and they failed to pull it off. I don't get why you're defending them like this? Especially now that they will be participating in those very decentralized projects like Gnome and Wayland where all participants are contributing.

@Jayofthezero: Wow, turns out the reason it wasn't working is that Windows marked my new router as a "Public" network. This applied more restrictive firewall rules, blocking Zeronet. Ironically UPNP isn't blocked though :P

@Musickiller: Yeah, you could do that. But some of the songs won't load unless the whole file is downloaded.

@Krixano: Yeah, that's built into FF now. My problems with it though are that the cookies are separated so I'd have to login multiple-times if I have several groups, and you can't hide tabs that aren't in a group so my tab bar gets filled with unrelated tabs. Right now with Tab Groups in FF56 tabs in other groups are hidden, I can freely switch between groups with a key combo, and there's a nice overview grid mode which makes it easy to drag multiple tabs between groups. While Containers is more of an advanced form of Private Tabs.

@Krixano: Tab Groups used to be built-into FF, but Mozilla removed it since they didn't feel it was worth the development time. But because of the wonders of open-source, somebody took the old code and turned it into an add-on so people could get the feature back, and eventually have it improved.
